children.subject:
My response mostly just applies to generic SWE. Many companies are looking for generalists, and especially in startups, a lot of it is learn-as-you-go.

Also, this paragraph applies largely to just startup companies. With all the jobs I've gotten, they've happened through networking. And to do networking, it is through getting lucky with opportunities and taking advantage of them. I used to be really unsatisfied with the answer that networking happens through luck. But I found out that it was true that most my friends and opportunities came from seemingly random encounters that I made the most of.

The less philosophical and more concrete part of my post is that I got my offers via meeting startup founders through various places such as meetups and hackathons. Then, I directly communicated with them to show that I was interested, and skipped the recruiter step. Talking to startup founders on a genuine level has personally gotten me pretty far.

Getting over imposter syndrome is something almost everyone has to take a while to deal with. Job requirements asking for a lot are often written by people to use it as a cheap tactic to weed out the applicant base. As a Cal student, you have already taken many EE/CS classes taught by great faculty and staff. Our EECS department is one of the best in the world with great pedagogy. So successfully studying CS at Cal already means that you already have a strong foundation and are probably qualified for many jobs out there.

Sorry if my post isn't too helpful. I could only answer to some specific experiences.
Could the OP talk about what fields they are specifically looking to get into? That would provide helpful context in answering the question.

history.content:
I'm a junior and I'm not sure which field of CS I want to work in. My experience so far has been pretty scattered (including research & SWE internships), but it seems like companies are all looking for people with depth of experience in one particular thing (my previous internships were in generic SWE and I got them very last-minute).

I feel frustrated because I'm not sure how I'm supposed to get depth of experience when clubs and research opportunities reject me. (I'm also not sure why internships are asking for depth of experience.) I don't want to spend my very limited free time working alone on side projects, but is that the only option? I already have one fairly substantial project which hasn't helped me in getting interviews for roles related to that project.

As a follow-up question, for fulltime positions, is the only way to get hired in a non-generic SWE role (say, ML / controls / operating systems / etc) to have some sort of side project or is coursework enough?
history.subject: How do I get hired?
